5. CUTICLE PREPARATIONS
rv 1 
1. Following an egg collection, incubate embryos for 24 at 250C.
2. Then remove chorion by gently rolling the eggs on "double-stick"
scotch tape.
3. Transfer embryos to a drop of Hoyer's Mounting Media (diluted with
lactic acid, 1:1) and then apply a coverslip.
4. Place slide ovemight on a warming plate.
References:
van der Meer, J. (1977) Drosophila I nf, 52, 160.
Wieschaus, E., and Niisslein-Volhard, C. (1986) Looking at Embryos. 
 a practical approach, D. B. Roberts IRL Press, Oxford, pp. 199-
227. (see below).
The following procedures for making cuticle prepartions are all minor variants of the
original technique described by van der Meer (24). The choice among procedures
depends on a balance between the desired quality of the preparation and the number
of different stocks and embryos to be examined.
5.1 Quick preparations of undechorionated eggs
This method may be used for determining hatch rates, embryonic phenotypes, etc.
Collect embryos and allow them to develop until all nonnal individuals have
hatched.
(ii) Determine the number of hatched eggs by counting the empty chorions on the
agar surface.
Pick the unhatched eggs from the plate with a forceps and transfer to a drop
of Hoyer's mountant on a glass slide.
(iv) Cover the drop with a small 10 mm) coverslip and incubate the preparation
ovemight at 
ithough the embryo is still covered by the chorion and some adherent yeast. it clears
.te well and the chorion pattern, although still visible, often does not interfere with
the analysis of the cuticular phenotype. The major advantage of this procedure is that
it is quick and no embryos are lost.
5.2 Standard preparations in the vitelline membrane
Remove the unhatched embryos from the plate with a small spatula or brush
and transfer to a wire basket made from stainless steel mesh. When embryos
from a number of stocks are to be processed at the same time, 'nets' with pos-
itions for seven stocks are convenient and time saving (see Section 7.2 for con-
struction of nets and baskets).
(ii) Dechorionate the eggs by transfening the net or basket to sodium hypochlorite
(commercial bleach, undiluted) in a 35-mm plastic Petri dish. The chorion has
been removed when the shiny surface of the vitelline membrane is visible and
the eggs have become hydrophobic when removed and retumed to the bleach,
they float on the surface due to surface tension).
Remove the net from the bleach, dry briefly on a paper towel, wash with a few
drops of water and retum to the emptied 35-mm Petri dish.
(iv) Add sufficient glycerinezacetic acid (l fixative to the dish to cover the eggs
but not enough to cause them to float up out of the basket.
Cover the Petri dish. place it inside a larger Petri dish to reduce evaporation,
and incubate for at 
(vi) Remove the dish from the oven and allow it to cool to room temperature.
Transfer the basket to a paper towel to remove excess fixative.
Scoop the eggs from the individual positions using a fute-tipped brush and transfer
them to a drop of Hoyer's mountant on a glass slide.
(ix) Cover them with a 10-mm or 18-mm coverslip and incubate at until the
intemal tissue clears (generally ovemight).

(vii)

To obtain better resolution 'pop` the vitelline membrane by pressing on the coverslip
after the embryos have cleared but before the Hoyer's mountant becomes too hard.
This is best done under a stereomicroscope. Retum the preparations to the oven to harden
flatten by wrapping them in aluminium foil and placing two or three weights
on the coverslip for 3 days. This procedure yields preparations of very high quality,
but it is cmcial that the preparation has cleared before the weights are added.
5.3 Embryos removed from their vitelline membranes
The greatest resolution of detail and the mos photogenic preparations are obtained when
the embryos are removed from the vitelline membrane prior to embedding. 'l'he following
procedure is particularly useful when all of the progeny from a cross must be examin-
ed regardless of whether or not they hatch.
Collect embryos at l2 intervals and allow them to develop an additional 6 
at Dechorionate in a stainless steel net in bleach and transfer to a plastic
Petri dish by inverting the net over the dish and gently squirting water through
the net. If the chorion has been completely removed the vitelline membrane will
Petridish.
(ii) Retum the Petri dish with the embryos still under water to for another
I8 -24 to allow all embryos to complete embryonic development. First instar
larvae that hatch remain in the water and eventually drown. After 24 h, remove
the vitelline membrane from embryos that do not hatch using a fine tungsten
or glass needle.
incubate larvae and hatched embryos in water for 30 min at before fix-
ation, remove the water and add 1:4 glycerinezacetic acid. Fix larvae in this sol-
ution for l5-60 min at Best results are obtained when preparations are
allowed to continue fixation at room temperature for at least 24 in the glycerine;
acetic acid.
(iv) Transfer the larvae individually to I-loyer's solution on a slide using a drawn
out mouth pipette or brush.
Add coverslips of the desired size and allow the preparations to clear at 
typically for 24 although they can usually be scored much earlier.
5.4 Other tricks for especially llat preparations of high contrast
When the coverslip is added, capillary action pulls the Hoyer's solution out over the
entire area covered. If exactly enough Hoyer's is used, this causes the embryo to flatten
gently under the coverslip without bursting. The Hoyer's mountant should not be too
viscous. Mount the embryos rapidly to prevent the I-loyer's from drying out on the
slide before the coverslip is added. Hoyer's which is too thick can be diluted with a
few drops of water. Peeled embryos can also be flattened with weights following the
procedures outlined in Section 5.2. lt is cmcial that the embryos first clear in the moun-
tant for several hours at before adding the weights.
For higher contrast, dilute the Hoyer's mountant 1:1 with lactic acid. Clearing time
is then reduced to at This procedure yields high contrast preparations par-
ticularly useful when the dorsal hair patterns must be analysed in detail. Unfortunate-
ly, the preparations tend to develop 
5.5 Analysis of cuticle patterm .
Examine cuticle preparations using a compound microscope equipped with objectives
for both dark field and phase contrast optics. As a simple substitute for true dark field
optics use low power objectives with the condenser in the phase contrast position (6.3
objectives with the condenser set at Ph 2; 10X or l6>< with the condenser in the Ph
3 position). Useful landmarks and aensilla in the external cuticle (25) and head (26.27)
are shown in Figures I0 and 11.
5.6 Photographing cuticle preparations
A high contrast film such as Kodak Technical Pan Film is most useful for photographing
details of the dorsal hair and denticle pattem as observed in phase contrast optics. For
dark field pictures of whole embryos, a lower contrast film like Kodak Panatomic-X
gives the best detail, although when using an automatic exposure meter the DIN setting
should be set higher than recommended, i.e. 23 rather than l6.
